body.p: Mohammed Aassila

A Heron triangle has integer sides and integer area; such a triangle is always the juxtaposition (in a positive or negative sense) of two pythagorean triangles along a common leg. The common leg may or may not be an integer, as in the triangles 131415(13,14,15)(13,14,15) and 52930(5,29,30)(5,29,30) respectively. There are still several nice open problems concerning Heron triangles. For example, it is not known if there exist Heron triangles having all medians integers, see 1345 for related problems and results.

In this note, we present some results on the existence of pairs of incongruent Heron triangles with the same area and with the same area and perimeter. We furthermore prove the existence of Heron triangles with prescribed inradius and circumradius. Throughout this note we denote by ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘a,b,ca,b,c the sides of a triangle and ğ‘†SS its area. The letters sğ‘Ÿs,r\mathrm{s},r and ğ‘…RR stand for the semiperimeter, inradius and circumradius respectively.
As a first result we prove the existence of pairs of incongruent Heron triangles with the same area. More precisely
Theorem 1 There are many pairs of incongruent Heron triangles having the same area.

Proof. As a second result in this note we have:
Theorem 2 There are infinitely many pairs of incongruent Heron triangles with the same area and perimeter.
Proof. Let ğ‘¡1tâ‰¥1t\geq 1 be any positive integer and let subscriptğ‘‡1T1T_{1} and subscriptğ‘‡2T2T_{2} be triangles of sides
and
Then, subscriptğ‘‡1T1T_{1} and subscriptğ‘‡2T2T_{2} are incongruent Heron triangles having the same semiperimeter
and the same area
We end this first part of the note by stating the following
Problem. Prove or disprove that for any positive integer ğ‘˜2kâ‰¥2k\geq 2 there exist ğ‘˜kk mutually incongruent Heron triangles having the same area and semiperimeter.
As a third result, we have:

Finally, the last result of this note is:
Theorem 4. Letğ‘ppbe a prime such thatğ‘1pâ‰¡1p\equiv 1 (mod 4). Then, there exists a Heron triangleğ‘‡TThavingğ‘…ğ‘R=p.R=p.
Proof Since ğ‘pp is a sum of two squares (see Dickson 2), we can write ğ‘superscriptğ‘¢2superscriptğ‘£2p=u2+v2.p=u^{2}+v^{2}. Then, the triangle of sides
is Heron and has ğ‘…superscriptğ‘¢2superscriptğ‘£2ğ‘R=u2+v2=pR=u^{2}+v^{2}=p. Indeed, this follows immediately from the fact that the above triangle is right angled.

Remark. It is clear from Theorem 4 that if ğ‘˜kk is an arbitrary positive integer which is a multiple of ğ‘pp, then there exists a Heron triangle of circumradius ğ‘…ğ‘˜R=kR=k. To see this, it suffices to consider the triangle which is similar to the triangle given by (4) but whose sides are ğ‘˜ğ‘k/pk/p times longer.
Since almost every integer is divisible by a prime ğ‘1pâ‰¡1p\equiv 1 (mod 4), the result of Theorem 4 is â€œalmostâ€ true in general, however we claim that:
Conjecture. Let ğ‘pp be a prime such that ğ‘11ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘‘12pâ‰¡11â¢(mâ¢oâ¢dâ¢12)p\equiv 11(mod12) . Then, there is no Heron triangle having ğ‘…ğ‘R=p.R=p.
